instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2978: What is 820-2978? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground after uc
threads.message:
working on this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had liquid damage all around the <CHIP>U2594</CHIP> area had to replace <CHIP>U2594</CHIP>,<CHIP>U6901</CHIP>,<CAPACITOR>C2599</CAPACITOR>,<RESISTOR>R2590</RESISTOR>,<CAPACITOR>C5025</CAPACITOR>,and <CAPACITOR>C4906</CAPACITOR>. a couple had blown off the legs on pp3v42 side or were super corroded but the machine still ran. so i replaced those and put in uc and now it doesnt power up. poked around and saw i am missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and have a short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>.

not really sure where to go on this but any help would be awesome.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2978</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground after uc
threads.message: okay not really sure what has happened here. i posted above took the board to my other desk and had a thought to plug in a 60w adapter. what do you know it fired right up. now it even fires with an 85w. not really sure how this could happen maybe the forum scared it into working again. problem solved
